repnme.cdata!: El Salvador - Second Land Administration Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the El Salvador Second Land
            Administration Project were as follows: the Bank performance
            was satisfactory, and the Borrower performance was
            unsatisfactory. The factor leading to the cancellation of
            the Project was the government's failure to gain
            consensus and obtain the second and final Congressional
            approval by a qualified (two thirds) majority required for
            approval of external borrowing and for project
            effectiveness. A lesson learned for the Bank is that in
            countries such as El Salvador where loans have to be
            ratified by a qualified majority of Congress, and the
            Congress is deeply divided, the Bank needs to recognize that
            loans may not be approved, despite every effort to meet with
            opposition leaders, explain the purposes of the projects,
            answer questions, provide information on previous
            operations, as well as information on the macroeconomic,
            fiscal and debt situation.

repnme.cdata!: El Salvador - Second Land Administration Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Second Land Administration Project
            for El Salvador aims at improving land tenure security and
            land transactions by providing efficient, equitable, and
            accessible land administration services. This will
            facilitate better land-related investments and more
            productive and environmentally sustainable land use. The
            project has the following three components: Component 1)
            will complete land regularization within El Salvador. In the
            context of LAP II, regularization refers to the systematic
            and massive dissemination campaign, mapping, verification of
            rights, delimitation of properties, resolution of field
            conflicts, notification of results, transfer of information
            to Property Registry and Cadastre Information System
            (SIRyC), and legalization and/or titling of lands in areas
            of social interest. Component 2) will improve the execution
            of day-to-day registry and cadastre services at local level
            (e.g., registration of titles, cadastral certificate
            emissions). Component 3) although National Registry Center
            (CNR) will be the sole implementing agency, it will deal
            with various participating institutions and partners.

5622845.trustfund:
TF053136-PHRD-EL SALVADOR: LAND
            ADMINISTRATION PROJECT II

repnme.cdata!:
El Salvador - Second Land Administration
            Project : environmental management plan

abstracts.cdata!:
The environmental management plan for
            the El Salvador Second Land Administration Project
            recommends several ways to enhance the project's
            positive impacts and mitigation measures to offset negative
            environmental effects that are expected. Among potential
            negative impacts are the following:  1) El Salvador-the most
            densely populated country in Latin America- is highly prone
            to natural disasters, including earthquakes, hurricanes, and
            volcanoes. In order to prevent the titling of parcels in
            risk-prone areas, the project will screen lands to be titled
            in risk areas and prohibit any titling activity in such
            areas.  2) There is no evidence linking the project's
            land administration activities (which do not include
            regularization of persons living in protected areas) with
            protected area encroachment. However, the project's
            communication strategy will include specific messages so as
            to minimize false expectations of persons currently living
            on state lands (protected areas and mangroves), explicitly
            to prevent short-term encroachment expansion. 3) Project
            procedures have been developed to ensure that in case
            project activities find evidence of cultural property on
            private lands, that information will be forwarded to CONCULTURA.

5540764.trustfund:
TF053136-PHRD-EL SALVADOR: LAND
            ADMINISTRATION PROJECT II

repnme.cdata!:
El Salvador - Second Land Administration
            Project : indigenous peoples plan

abstracts.cdata!:
The Second Land Administration Project
            aims to improve land tenure security and land transactions,
            by providing efficient, equitable, and accessible land
            administration services. This will facilitate better
            land-related investments, and more productive and
            environmentally sustainable land use. However, and as
            specified within the social assessment, a major project risk
            is the political factor, namely that the project might be an
            instrument that favors particular groups over others. This
            Indigenous Peoples Plan (IPP) sets the measures to ensure
            all groups, i.e., indigenous populations, ethnic groups, and
            minorities, benefit from implementation of the project. The
            National Registry Center (CNR) will be responsible for
            implementing awareness campaigns informing on the potential
            project benefits, as well as location of the project area,
            and activities to be developed. This will be achieved within
            the first project component, through media communication,
            particularly targeting isolated rural areas. In addition,
            under the second component, capacity building should ensure
            that beneficiaries are aware of their rights and
            responsibilities in terms of land tenure, including of
            procedures and land registry costs, and legal issues. This
            will also be the responsibility of the CNR, and of lawyers
            who will be directly involved in capacity building. Finally,
            under the third component, a monitoring and evaluation
            program will be in place to process household surveys and
            data gathered, ensure compliance with specified safeguards,
            and provide grievance mechanisms, should conflict occur.
